results.title: Gently down the stream
results.creator_credit: Ray Costello and Education Department Western Australia
results.brief_description: Shows a Year 10 canoeing expedition on the river from Mt Franklin to the Noralup inlet, Western Australia. Demonstrates that the focus of the Outdoor Education Project is preparation for expeditions; and shows the basic understandings for wilderness and adventure activities.

results.title: Generation on the wind
results.creator_credit: David A. Vassar, Joel Silverman, Samanther Shadd and Windmill Movie Company
results.brief_description: Details the year long construction of a wind generator on the small island of Cutty Hunk off the New England coast by a group of men who apply collective skills to a task new to all of them.

results.title: Geelong
results.creator_credit: John Porter and Eric Porter Productions
results.brief_description: On the shores of Corio Bay, 45 miles from Melbourne, the great factories of Geelong beat out a productive rhythm. People flock to the beach resorts of Torquay, Anglesea and Lorne; from Australian Rules to the Great Ocean Road, this film acts as a brochure to Victoria’s second largest city.

results.title: Gathering of the clans
results.brief_description: Scenes at the Gathering of the Clans held at Inverness in 1966. Traditional dancing, sports and the pipe band contest are shown. The history of Scottish culture as represented at the Gathering is briefly discussed.

results.title: Gateway to independence
results.brief_description: A guide dog gives independence to a blind person. Shows the careful selection and training of dogs and the training of the people who will use these dogs as aids to daily living. It stresses that complete confidence in the dog by its owner is essential for the success of the enterprise. Cinematography by Tom Cowan.

results.title: Gateway to a city
results.creator_credit: Roderick Johnston and Roderick Films International
results.brief_description: A brief history of the area near Circular Quay, Sydney, known as The Rocks. Shows how this valuable site has become a neglected backwater and indicates, by the use of models, how it will look in the near future after redevelopment.

results.title: Gardens of Japan
results.brief_description: Some of the scenic beauty of Japan - in nature and in the highly cultivated and famous gardens in Tokyo and Kyoto; a variety of gardens which have been planned and cultivated to please both the mind and the eye, including those using sand and stone to represent natural landscapes and which have symbolic signifance. A short sequence shows the traditional tea ceremony. A revised version of Title Codes 004193 and 004194.

results.title: Gaps
results.brief_description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. ‘Gaps’ embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship - or ‘gaps’ - between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on ‘Gaps’ include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed ‘How to Feel’ 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period. Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.
results.description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, David Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. Gaps embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship – or ‘gaps’ – between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period.

Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.

One of Australia’s finest video artists, David Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. Gaps embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship – or ‘gaps’ – between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period.

Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.

details.label: Measurements
display_values:
Duration: 35 mins, 7 seconds
The work does not need to be seen from beginning to end, viewers are invited to approach and engage with the work at any point throughout the duration.

production_dates.notes:
Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney).
David Rosetzky: Gaps will be a free exhibition at ACMI from 5 August 2014 to 8 February 2015.
The co-commission of Gaps by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts, its arts funding and advisory body.

results.title: Game hunting in the Arctic Regions (D)
results.brief_description: A silent documentary film with English subtitles, about an arctic sea voyage and game hunting in the north of Norway, and around Spitzbergen and Bear Island. WARNING: CONTAINS IMAGES OF DYING ANIMALS, BUTCHERING CARCASES AND CAGING WHICH MAY DISTURB SOME VIEWERS.
